title: Black women are too often overlooked. I will not be silenced
text:
Steve Wilson, a Lib Dem member who works in Parliament, decided to correct my experience of racism (Picture: Steve Wilson/Twitter; PA)

In my last Metro article, I referred to being mistaken for a cleaner when I was in the Members’ lift in Parliament. There is absolutely nothing wrong with being a cleaner, but the fact that someone questioned my profession because of the colour of my skin is racial prejudice.

In response to my article, a Lib Dem member who works in Parliament decided to correct my experience, he tried to undermine and belittle me. Steve Wilson is his name and he tried to gaslight me and essentially he told me to shut up and stop talking about racism.

Steve Wilson actually wrote ‘this is not true’. I still find it hard to believe why he would write such a strong statement. He then went on to say that accounts like mine ‘don’t do anyone justice and anyone propagating them should stop it’. So he called me a liar and told me to stop talking about racism.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Well, in the words of Labi Siffre, ‘the more you refuse to hear my voice the louder I will sing’.

In order to stamp out racism we have to expose it in all of its ugliness – and Steve’s comments to me were ugly. And the fact that he works for Angela Smith MP, who once appeared to described people of colour as having a ‘funny tinge’, worries me.

To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

With this combination, what would be their attitude to people of colour who contact their office desperate for an MP’s help because they have suffered discrimination? Steve has already shown to me that as a privileged white man, racism just doesn’t exist. It is just not true. And his non-apology apology just to a newspaper was frankly an insult.

I am still waiting for an apology from him.

Racism is on the rise, many witnessed the sickening scenes during the England v Bulgaria football match recently which was halted twice due to Nazi salutes and monkey noises. If it had been stopped a third time the game would have been abandoned. I was impressed with England and Brent’s very own Raheem Sterling who I have known since he was around 10 years old.

It is important to support people who are being racially abused (Picture: Catherine Ivill/Getty Images)

But why should they have to put up with three incidents of racism before decisive action is taken? This racism is happening at every level of the football pyramid and that is why it is so important to call it out, that is why it is important to support people who are being racially abused. If you have never experienced it then feel lucky and be a good ally to those who have, and those who suffer every single day.

Advertisement

Advertisement

You can see the bemusement and hurt in Prince Harry’s eyes when he has to talk about the abuse that his wife, the Duchess of Sussex, suffers so regularly. Anyone watching the documentary this week felt the pain through the screen – it was palpable and those of us who are woke or women of colour knew the word the Duchess was avoiding saying was she was subjected to more abuse because of racism. The Duchess spoke about fairness – just be fair.

If you have never experienced racism then feel lucky and be a good ally to those who have, and those who suffer every single day (Picture: ITV)

For Black women not being heard, being overlooked, undermined, underestimated and ridiculed happens far too often but it doesn’t mean that we will keep quiet about it. And the fact that social media allows us to be connected has made us stronger in our fight for a fairer society.

So if Steve thinks I am going to shut up and stop talking about it, he can think again. I am waiting for an acknowledgement from his party leader Jo Swinson, and I am still waiting for an apology from Steve Wilson. I will not be silenced.
